In a surprising revelation, Lisa Vanderpump opened up about her lack of communication with Raquel Leviss since the highly dramatic season 10 reunion of "Vanderpump Rules." The SUR restaurant boss admitted that the intense emotions displayed during the finale episode were difficult for her to watch, as she felt a sense of heartbreak for both Tom Sandoval and Leviss, despite condemning Sandoval's actions. Raquel Leviss and Lisa Vanderpump.  During a recent interview with ET, Vanderpump shared that she has not been in contact with Raquel Leviss since the season 10 reunion, which was filmed on March 23. When asked about the future of Leviss and Sandoval in the "Vanderpump Rules" universe following their scandalous affair, the "Real Housewives of Beverly Hills" star revealed that she hasn't had any recent communication with Leviss.  She expressed that Leviss needs to discuss what's happening in her life with the group, while also acknowledging Sandoval's longstanding presence within the cast and their business collaborations.  Vanderpump stated, "You know, four years before the show... That's what I hope for them. I don't think you can just shut the door on somebody. I think we're all guilty of some things... maybe not that. But there must be some discussion, and I think we'll be there for it."  Vanderpump further admitted that the finale episode of "Vanderpump Rules" was particularly challenging for her to watch. She disclosed that the episode was filmed some time after the completion of the season, making the emotions raw and palpable. As a producer, Vanderpump usually enjoys the "ins and outs and shenanigans" of the show, but it becomes more challenging when she becomes emotionally invested in the group.  Despite condemning Sandoval's actions, Vanderpump confessed that her heart broke for both him and Leviss. She stated, "Of course, what he did... it cannot be condoned in any way, shape, or form. But still, to see the utter misery and the devastation of the fallout."  These revelations come in the wake of Sandoval and Leviss' separation, which occurred just two months after their affair was exposed, leading to the end of Sandoval's nine-year relationship with Ariana Madix. During the season 10 finale, Vanderpump had a conversation with Sandoval, showcasing her unique approach to supporting this group of friends.  She revealed that she doesn't adhere to strict rules and chose not to "pile on" the catastrophe by taking sides. Vanderpump emphasized that she condemned Sandoval's actions but couldn't write him off as a person because of one mistake. She explained her perspective by saying, "I feel like a mother to some of these children. So, when he's been criticized by the whole world, what will I do, pile on? No, I'm going to try and have a modicum of... not empathy, I don't have empathy... but a modicum of hope. Maybe for the future."  In April, Leviss sought treatment at a facility to address her mental health, as confirmed by a source. Leviss and her family had decided on this course of action before the affair was exposed, and Bravo and production were aware and supportive of her journey toward better mental health.  As the fallout from the scandal continues, Leviss released a statement in March acknowledging her behavior and commitment to self-reflection. She mentioned seeking guidance from a counselor and understanding her patterns of codependency and addiction to feeling loved. Leviss expressed her desire to make healthier choices and prioritize her well-being over unhealthy intimate connections that may negatively affect others and her friendships.  Also read | | Here's Ariana Madix, Lisa Vanderpump's relationship status amid Scandoval drama  With the absence of communication between Vanderpump and Leviss, the future dynamics of the "Vanderpump Rules" cast remain uncertain. Fans eagerly await further developments and revelations as the show continues to captivate audiences with its gripping drama.

If you were to make a wild stab at which books were the most popular, what would you choose? Your personal favourites ‚Äî say, mysteries, or big sagas, blockbuster reads from writers such as John Irving or Stephen King?  The book industry is having a fine romance: with books about love.  Romance for a new generation  One of the authors who has helped cement the place of romance in the popular imagination ‚Äî or at least on the bestsellers lists ‚Äî is Colleen Hoover. Her ‚ÄúIt Ends With Us‚Äù was the No. 1 bestselling book in Canada in 2022. According to BookNet Canada, Hoover‚Äôs books alone drove a 55-per-cent increase in the romance category when compared with 2021, with five of her titles topping the list.  The same trend was seen in the United States. Publishers Weekly reported that ‚Äúunit sales of fiction titles rose 8.5 per cent over 2021, led by a 52.4-per-cent increase in sales of romance books.‚Äù And those sales were driven in large part by, you guessed it, Colleen Hoover.  ‚ÄúThe list of bestselling romance titles in 2022 is ‚Ä¶ led by Colleen Hoover, whose ‚ÄòIt Starts With Us‚Äô and ‚ÄòIt Ends With Us‚Äô topped the romance charts. Those two books, along with a handful of other Hoover titles, resulted in a banner year for Simon & Schuster ‚Ä¶‚Äù  Hoover is published in Canada by Simon & Schuster, which noted in an email to the Star that the author has sold more than 24 million copies of her English-language books ‚Äúin all formats‚Äù across the world. It has seen its sales of romance books ‚Äúskyrocket‚Äù as a result.  Much of this traffic is driven by younger readers. According to BookNet Canada, the hashtag #RomanceRecs has more than 390 million views on TikTok, ‚Äúan undeniable source of influence on book-reading behaviour.‚Äù It‚Äôs an observation that Simon & Schuster echoes.  ‚ÄúAn increasing number of younger, and often more diverse readers have discovered and embraced this genre, much of it fuelled by BookTok,‚Äù the publisher said in a statement. ‚ÄúWhere sales have traditionally been driven by retailer merchandising and press coverage, a lot of the original buzz for these books was driven by enthusiastic BookTok readers.‚Äù  The Harlequin effect  There used to be a saying: that 4.1 Harlequin romances sold around the world every second. That particular publisher was, at one time, the first name that sprang to mind when the words ‚Äúbooks‚Äù and ‚Äúromance‚Äù were mentioned.  And it‚Äôs still going strong. Dianne Moggy, vice-president of editorial for the Harlequin Brand Group, which includes 11 category lines, noted that they publish more than 800 romance titles a year. And they‚Äôre not all those paperbacks we remember from our parents‚Äô bookcases or grocery store shelves: roughly 40 per cent of their books sell digitally.  The genre‚Äôs popularity has driven a deep change in the content of books and an increased focus on giving readers what they want.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve really been trying to increase the representation across every series we publish,‚Äù Moggy said. ‚ÄúSo we‚Äôre trying to ensure that our readers are actually seeing themselves reflected in the books ‚Ä¶ whether it‚Äôs race and ethnicity or body image or neurodiversity.‚Äù  Those concerns have translated into sales in the Canadian market. BookNet Canada recorded that sales in romance featuring LGBTQ characters increased by 10,406 per cent between 2017 and 2022, with sales from 2020 to ‚Äô21 increasing 301 per cent, and from ‚Äô21 to ‚Äô22 by 136 per cent. Fiction romance in the workplace rose by 1,793 per cent during that five-year period, and for African American and Black categories by 1,733 per cent.  The desire for more representative romance is an aspect of the genre that attracts Muslim writer Uzma Jalaluddin, whose latest, ‚ÄúMuch Ado About Nada,‚Äù comes out in June.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm attracted to the subversive aspects of romance, the ways that romance writers (like myself) use the tropes and expectations of this genre to explore other issues, such as identity, immigration or prejudice,‚Äù she said. And so she writes love stories set in immigrant neighbourhoods with South Asian, Muslim characters.  ‚ÄúWhen I wrote ‚ÄòMuch Ado About Nada‚Äô I set it in a massive Muslim conference in Toronto,‚Äù said Jalaluddin. ‚ÄúAs much as my book is a swoony second-chance romance, it‚Äôs also about Muslims having fun and inviting the reader into their space.  ‚ÄúAfter all, love is love no matter who you are, how you dress or what you believe. Also, no one else was writing them. (I‚Äôm glad that‚Äôs changing now.)‚Äù  Stomping on the tropes and using them in new ways  HarperCollins, whose parent company News Corp. bought Harlequin from the Toronto Star‚Äôs parent company, Torstar Corp., for $455 million in 2014, is like many publishers, increasing the number of trade paperback or hardcover romances it offers.  ‚ÄúI think the definition of romance has spilled into a number of different areas,‚Äù said Margaret O‚ÄôNeill Marbury, a VP at HarperCollins, responsible for trade titles at the company that owns Harlequin.  Popular American writer Curtis Sittenfeld, who publishes with Random House, has recently waded into the genre with her latest novel, ‚ÄúRomantic Comedy.‚Äù  It sets up an interesting dynamic, showing at first the typical dorky, not-so-good-looking guy with the gorgeous model. Then she flips that trope on its head by having the dorky, not-so-gorgeous writer develop a crush on a famous pop star who used to date models.  The book becomes an examination of gender relations and the rituals of romance, yes, but it also does something traditional romances do: has an emotional arc, strong characters you can relate to, some drama that keeps them apart and, well, a happy ending.  ‚ÄúI thought that it would be fun. That was my main motivation. I started it in the summer of 2021,‚Äù said Sittenfeld in an interview. ‚ÄúSo it was the pandemic, I guess it was about 15 months or 16 months in, and it felt like a pretty dark time, I think, globally and personally. I definitely wrote ‚ÄòRomantic Comedy‚Äô for escapist pleasure for myself. And then I hoped, eventually, for readers.‚Äù  ‚ÄúSome people will say that romance is just ChickLit reinvented,‚Äù said Canadian author Chantel Guertin, whose latest book is ‚ÄúTwo for the Road.‚Äù  She argued that romance now is not ‚Äúa 20-something girl who‚Äôs bumbling through life trying to find a guy. Now the heroines are so strong and they are self-assured, and very successful and have great careers. That romance element is part of it, but as a person they have got it figured out.‚Äù  And, while in the more traditional romance, the happy ending is a must, commercial or trade fiction stories don‚Äôt always have to have one, Marbury said, ‚Äúbut they do have to be hopeful,‚Äù and there still has to be a strong relationship or pull between the characters. Think of writers such as Nicholas Sparks, Emily Giffin and Jojo Moyes.  The ‚Äúhappily ever after‚Äù is the point  But the happy ending has a big role to play, and a lot of readers and writers like it that way.  Romance book sales grew throughout the pandemic, a time of uncertainty, as Guertin pointed out. ‚ÄúWe often felt as if we had no control of our situations and we certainly didn‚Äôt know what things were going to look like in the next few months.  ‚ÄúOnce you know the book is going to end happily, you remove that layer of unsettling and uncertainty, and then you actually enjoy the ride of the journey of the story, which actually is often very complex,‚Äù Guertin said. ‚ÄúAnd you can really delve into the characters and their stories because you‚Äôre not concerned about how it‚Äôs going to end.‚Äù  And you can escape from the reality of the everyday.  Jalaluddin, too, is a believer in the happily-ever-after ending. ‚ÄúPartly this is because I‚Äôm a hopeless romantic, wrapped in the outer trappings of a cynic,‚Äù she said.  ‚ÄúBut mostly it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm attracted to optimistic stories that demonstrate the good in humanity; and romance novels, with their focus on love, relationships, problem-solving, a dash of adventure or intrigue, are at their heart heaped with optimism. It is baked into the very DNA of the genre, because no matter what else happens there will be a happy ending for all. Who can resist that?‚Äù  Certainly not the readers buying those millions of romance books being sold every year and those who, during the pandemic, turned to the genre for an emotional and psychological lift.  Can artificial intelligence write us a love story?  As romance continues to modernize its approach, it seems as if it might be particularly vulnerable to being written, perhaps unknowingly to readers, by artificial intelligence, including ChatGPT and others. With its fairly predictable structure, it would seem a particularly promising genre for AI to target.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not looking to AI to generate content at all,‚Äù said Moggy. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a big concern in terms of the number of submissions we get and how do we police that?‚Äù  She noted that they received a submission earlier in the week we spoke and weren‚Äôt sure whether it was AI-generated or not. ‚ÄúBut it certainly is very similar to another book we have published.‚Äù  While AI might be helpful in terms of writing marketing copy based on metadata, for example, when it comes to the creative process and content, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs where I get very nervous about things,‚Äù said Marbury.  It‚Äôs romance, after all. And doesn‚Äôt it all come down to love? Can an algorithm capture emotion? It‚Äôs a question we‚Äôve been asking since Hal in ‚Äú2001: A Space Odyssey.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôve hit the real point here,‚Äù said Moggy. ‚ÄúCan it bring the emotion, which is what the reader connects to ‚Ä¶ if that emotion is missed, then I think you‚Äôd miss what the romance reader is looking for.‚Äù  Hopefully, for the industry ‚Äî and writers and readers ‚Äî this will result in a happy ending. A star whose life ended in a cataclysmic explosion has been recorded by the recently installed National Astronomical Observatory in Gozo.  The star lies in the so-called Pinwheel Galaxy (M101) which lies around 21 million light years away.  ‚ÄúThis means that the event actually happened 21 million years ago, the light of the explosion having travelled across the universe since that time until it finally reached us,‚Äù said Prof. Joseph Caruana, from the University of Malta‚Äôs Department of Physics and Institute of Space Sciences and Astronomy.  The event in question is known as a Type II supernova. This occurs when a massive star ‚Äì several times more massive than our sun ‚Äì is unable to sustain nuclear fusion any further, thus undergoing a rapid collapse that ends with a catastrophic explosion.  The supernova, dubbed SN 2023ixf, was reported on the 19 May by Koichi Itagaki. A notification system for astronomers around the world allows them to follow up with further observations.  ‚ÄúYesterday, some amongst the amateur astronomy community in Malta ‚Äì the Astronomical Society of Malta ‚Äì were already discussing this object with us,‚Äù said Caruana, who recorded the image throughout the night of Saturday 20 and Sunday 21 May, remarking that it was quite exciting to witness such an event just a few days after the observatory in Gozo had started operating.  ‚ÄúWhen you look at the image, the supernova looks just like a tiny dot amongst many others. But that tiny dot represents an extremely violent event whose light has travelled an immense distance. It really gives you pause.‚Äù  Astronomers around the world ‚Äì both professional and amateur ‚Äì will be turning their telescopes to this object over the coming days. Observations of such events often involve collaboration between professional and amateur astronomers.

The incident creates a big ruckus at the theater towards evacuating the audience amid the slogans, shouting, and screaming in the corridors.  The over-excited fans ended up lighting crackers inside the theater where SImhadri was playing has resulted in smoke and fire.  A fire just broke out in one of the big screen rooms of Hounslow Cineworld pic.twitter.com/YnGkxebaUl ‚Äî UB1UB2 SOUTHALL (@UB1UB2) May 19, 2023  A London Fire Brigade spokesperson confirmed that there was no fire. They said, ‚ÄòThe alarm is believed to have been caused by a smoke device being set off. There were no reports of any injuries but the cinema was evacuated as a precaution. We were called at 10.13 pm and the incident was over for our firefighters by 10.39 pm.‚Äô  The video came out posted by the Hounslow Cineworld and is now going viral. With the latest incident in London for Simhadri, the re-releases of yesteryear blockbusters may remain a dream, just because of the irresponsible behavior of fans in the name of celebration. The Caloocan City Police Station (CCPS) reported that a man fired a handgun and lobbed a grenade in front of the office of the Northern Police District- Drug Enforcement Unit (NPD-DEU) in Barangay 14, Caloocan City on Saturday, May 20.  Gen. Ponce Rogelio Pe√±ones, Northern Police District (NPD) director, said they have already identified the suspect.  According to the police report, the man immediately fled towards Pampano Street after firing his handgun and throwing a hand grenade that exploded in front of the office near the Criminal Investigation and Detection Group (CIDG) office at around 1:45 a.m.  The CCPS Explosive Ordinance Division (EOD) recovered three fired cartridges, a slug, and metallic fragment from the exploded MK-2 hand grenade.  CCPS Chief Col. Ruben Lacuesta said the explosion damaged the front stairs of the police station.  He said that they also found bullet holes in the office‚Äôs main door and on the surface of the car parked in front of the office.  Authorities have withheld the identity of the suspect who is now the subject of a manhunt launched by the CCPS.  Investigators are eyeing retaliation against the police anti-illegal drugs campaign as one of the possible motives behind the attack.  No one was reported injured in the incident.

BENTON ‚Äî For the first time since 2019, residents, vendors and visitors flocked to the Benton Alewife Festival on Saturday to celebrate the native fish‚Äôs resurgence in recent years.  The festival began in 2012, but was canceled for a few years due to the coronavirus pandemic. It celebrates the annual alewife migration, when the fish travel upstream for about a month in the spring to reach lakes and ponds to spawn.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hoping to continue bringing a greater awareness to the importance of the alewives and the Sebasticook River, and also to come together as a community,‚Äù said organizer Amy Gagnon earlier this week.  Festivalgoers congregated Saturday at the Benton Riverside Park by the town hall to browse stalls offering food, canned goods, wood carving demonstrations and information on local wildlife including alewives. People could then migrate down a walking path from the park to the Benton Falls Dam for a tour of the fish lift at the dam. Live music from bluegrass band The Oystermen provided the day‚Äôs soundtrack.  At Benton Falls, tens of people at a time lined the dam, leaning over the railings to catch a glimpse of the millions of fish passing over using a fish elevator.  It‚Äôs a recent marvel: for decades, alewives‚Äô migration up the Sebasticook River was blocked. In 2008, the fish population at Benton Falls was estimated at just 400,000.  Advertisement  But the removal of the Edwards Dam on the Kennebec River in Augusta and the Fort Halifax Dam in Winslow, along with other restoration efforts, now allow the fish to travel up again. In 2022, there were an estimated 2.7 million fish counted at Benton Falls Dam, according to the Maine Department of Marine Resources.  Festivalgoers were eager to celebrate that fact on Saturday for the first time in years.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to have these kinds of community events opening up again,‚Äù said Benton-based forest ranger Timothy Kjellman. Kjellman was on hand to represent the Maine Forest Service and teach local kids about fire safety and wildfire prevention.  A couple vendors had made an annual appearance at the festival before it was suspended, including wood carving instructor Steven Valleau, an artist-in-residence at the Wendell Gilley Museum in Southwest Harbor.  ‚ÄúI feel like now I‚Äôm back here, COVID is officially over,‚Äù Valleau joked. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs awesome.‚Äù  Also returning with a stall were representatives from the Sebasticook River Land Trust, on hand to explain to people headed down to the falls the importance of alewives to the area, and raise awareness about ongoing conservation efforts across the watershed.  Advertisement  Doug Wescott, a land trust board member, said that alewives are hugely important to the region‚Äôs watershed.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a big issue in a lot of lakes in Maine with phosphorus,‚Äù Wescott said.  Phosphorus is an essential nutrient for plant life but when there is too much of it in water it can speed up something called eutrophication, which causes a dense growth of algae and depletes oxygen levels.  Alewives, Wescott said, eat the algae produced by excess nutrients in the lake like phosphorus, effectively cleaning up the lake and mitigating the potential for an algal bloom.  The removal of the dams was a godsend to the Sebasticook River watershed, Wescott said. ‚ÄúThey were interfering with natural processes ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think anyone knew at the time how many alewives would come here.‚Äù  Since then, the Sebasticook has become one of the biggest alewife runs on the East Coast. Wescott said that the 5-mile section of the Sebasticook River in Benton and Winslow has become the area with the largest concentration of bald eagles on the East Coast.  ‚ÄúAnd it‚Äôs all because of the alewives,‚Äù he said.  Related Headlines The alewife has seen a resurgence, and now a Benton festival returns to honor the native fish  Send questions/comments to the editors.  ¬´ Previous  Next ¬ª  filed under:

SAN DIEGO (AP) ‚Äî Rafael Devers homered twice and drove in four runs to help the Boston Red Sox beat San Diego 6-1 Friday night to hand the staggering Padres their 10th loss in 12 games.  Devers and his friend and former teammate, Padres shortstop Xander Bogaerts, took the lineup cards out for the pregame exchange and hugged. Devers then circled the bases in front of Bogaerts in consecutive innings in his 14th career multi-homer game.  Devers hit a solo shot to right so hard leading off the second that he stumbled back a few steps before starting his trot. He hit a three-run homer nearly to the base of the batter's eye in straightaway center field with no outs in the five-run third for a 6-0 lead. He has 13 homers this season.  Both came off lefty Blake Snell (1-6), who allowed six runs and five hits in four innings.  Before the game, Bogaerts said he hoped Devers didn't hit any homers because ‚Äúhe's a dangerous guy. He's truly one of a kind."  Devers proved his friend right.  ‚ÄúVery happy today that I was able to hit two runs but you have to keep doing adjustments every day,‚Äù Devers said through a translator.  ‚ÄúHe put two great swings,‚Äù manager Alex Cora said. ‚ÄúAround him, everybody put up good at-bats. That was impressive, the third inning. We were grinding at-bats, fouling off pitches, staying on pitches, taking our walks. It was a fun inning.‚Äù  Rob Refsnyder hit a two-run, bases-loaded double ahead of Devers' three-run shot to help the Red Sox to their third straight win.  Other than Fernando Tatis Jr.'s leadoff homer in the third off James Paxton (1-0), the Padres' offensive struggles continued on a day when slugger Manny Machado went on the 10-day injured list with a hairline fracture in his left hand. The Padres were booed at game's end, just as they were Wednesday after a loss to Kansas City. They fell to five games under .500 and are 8 1/2 games behind the NL West-leading Los Angeles Dodgers and just one game ahead of the last-place Colorado Rockies.  The Padres managed just Tatis' homer, his sixth, and four singles in six innings off Paxton, who was making only his second start of 2023. He made his Red Sox debut a week earlier, his first big league appearance since April 6, 2021, with Seattle. He missed most of the 2020-22 seasons due to injuries and had Tommy John surgery on April 12, 2021.  ‚ÄúIt feels great, just really to contribute to the team and be here pitching again,‚Äù said Paxton, who earned his first victory since Aug. 15, 2020, against Boston while he was with the New York Yankees.  Paxton said Devers is "awesome. His swing is amazing. So good on offense and he does a great job at third base, too. Just an all-around fantastic player, fun to watch.‚Äù  Josh Winckowski pitched the final three innings for his second save.  Bogaerts, who left the Red Sox as a free agent and signed a $280 million, 11-year contract in December, was robbed of a single by diving right fielder Alex Verdugo to end the fifth.  EXPLOSION IN SINGLE-A CLUBHOUSE  Two contract workers were burned in a natural gas explosion in the home clubhouse of the Lake Elsinore Storm, the Padres' Class-A affiliate, leading to Friday's game being postponed. The two workers were taken to a hospital. The Padres said no players were involved.  DEVERS AND BOGEY  Devers and Bogaerts went out to eat Thursday, an off day for both teams. ‚ÄúYou know what's crazy is, I forgot my wallet at home. I'm not even kidding," Bogaerts said. He thought he left it at the ballpark but didn't find it there, and started to get nervous. ‚ÄúI said, 'Man, you've got to pick this up. I don't even have a dollar.'" Bogaerts said he found his wallet at home, in his backpack, where he put it during the bus ride home from Dodger Stadium last Sunday. ‚ÄùI haven't told him that piece yet but I told him right away that he's got to pay,‚Äù Bogaerts said.  TRAINER'S ROOM  Red Sox: 1B Justin Turner, who was aboard for Devers' three-run shot, left the game with left knee soreness.  Padres: Machado's was hurt when he was hit by a pitch Monday night. His IL stint is retroactive to Tuesday. Manager Bob Melvin said there‚Äôs a possibility Machado can return when the Padres play at the New York Yankees next weekend.  UP NEXT  Saturday night's game will feature a marquee matchup between Red Sox LHP Chris Sale (3-2, 5.40 ERA) and Padres RHP Joe Musgrove (1-1, 6.63).

GRAND ISLAND, Neb. (KSNB) - When it comes to bombs and explosives we often think of police department bomb squad, but firefighters have some knowledge on that too.  During the 86th annual Nebraska State Fire School, they learned about explosives in one of the featured classes.  Nebraska State Patrol educated firefighters about different elements that compose an explosive device. They even were treated to seeing a few explosions to understand the power packed in each kind of explosive.  ‚ÄúMany people don‚Äôt think about that,‚Äô said Jimmy Lawson, Class Coordinator at Nebraska State Fire School. ‚ÄúThat this is going to be a situation involving some type of explosive but they need at least the basic training. Enough to understand the dangers, safety precautions, and certainly enough to protect themselves before they go rushing in and getting hurt themselves.‚Äù  For some firefighters, it was about just knowing the resources exist.  ‚ÄúWell I think that we learned that we have, that Nebraska has available resources for us as firefighters and the general public and that it happens more than you think and that it‚Äôs all about safety; so we learned a lot today,‚Äù said Kalah Bergmann, firefighter at Gretna Fire Department.  Fellow Gretna firefighter, Sarah Graselwicz said she learned how to recognize explosives and will be able to used that each time she responses to a call.  Copyright 2023 KSNB. All rights reserved.

MEXICO CITY ‚Äì Clouds of ash from explosions inside one of Mexico‚Äôs most active volcanoes has forced authorities to issue alerts for millions of residents and triggered the temporary shut of Mexico City‚Äôs Benito Ju√°rez International Airport on Saturday.  Cameras pointed at the Popocat√©petl volcano, which is about 40 miles southeast of the capital city, have shown increased clouds of gasses and ash leaving the volcano after a reported uptick of activity inside the mountain.  The Mexican government has issued a yellow alert and urged residents to stay away from the volcano due to falling debris.  Earlier in the week, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs reported communities nearest to Popocat√©petl closed schools and opened evacuation shelters.  According to the Global Volcanism Program, the current eruption cycle has been ongoing since 2005 and has included numerous episodes of increased emissions.  4 CLASSIC TYPES OF VOLCANOES  next Image 1 of 4  prev next Image 2 of 4  prev next Image 3 of 4  prev Image 4 of 4  During the shutdown of Mexico‚Äôs busiest airport, personnel inspected and cleaned critical infrastructure from ash.  Planes are highly susceptible to volcanic material, and the U.S. Geological Survey reported there have been 79 cases of ash damaging aircraft worldwide since 1953.  Ash particles can damage a plane‚Äôs fuselage, blades and greatly hinder an engine‚Äôs performance and electronics.  So far, local authorities have reported only minor-to-moderate explosions occurring in Popocat√©petl.  A significant eruption could impact millions of residents who live in the potential ash impact zone.  MT. ST. HELENS‚Äô ERUPTION: SURVIVORS RECOUNT THE ‚ÄòDARKER THAN MIDNIGHT‚Äô FURY IN 1980  Mexico is no stranger to volcanic activity due to its location along the Pacific Ring of Fire.  The country is home to dozens of volcanic mountains, with several that are considered to be active.

At a vicious PGA Championship, the only joy is misery  Share on Facebook  Share on Twitter  Share by Email  Rory McIlroy survived through a brutal Saturday at the PGA. He's one of the few. Getty Images  ROCHESTER, N.Y. ‚Äî As he stood over the chip on the 17th hole that could well sink his PGA Championship, Rory McIlroy looked, well, miserable.  His face wore a pained expression. His hands fidgeted in small, sudden movements. He talked with his caddie and longtime friend, Harry Diamond, in frustrated quips. He walked in staccato strides to the green and back, searching for some clue on how to execute.  He stepped up to the ball. He paused. He stepped away. He stepped up again. He committed.  And then ‚Ä¶ an explosion of sound ‚Äî not the literal kind ‚Äî erupting from the 15th green just a 5-iron away.  Rory stepped off his ball again. He turned back to Harry exasperated. If looks could kill, McIlroy‚Äôs might well have had the strength of a cruise missile.  But looks can‚Äôt kill, and so Rory had no choice but to play his short-sided wedge shot off a tight, greenside lie and up toward the flagstick ‚Ä¶ for par. For the moment, the cruise missile sounded better.  His ball scared the hole for just a second, electing instead to settle neatly just a short putt away. McIlroy would have to take bogey, his fourth and final of the day at Oak Hill. As he walked away from the flagstick he looked up at the sky. For the moment, his tournament had been saved.  McIlroy is a demonstrative golfer, but his experience on Saturday afternoon at the PGA Championship was not an unusual one. Misery was the only path to contention on Saturday at Oak Hill, which has proven as proper and demanding a major championship test as we have seen in professional golf in some time.  Misery in the rain. Misery in the mud. Misery off the tee. Misery around the green. It was everywhere.  The only people who managed were those with the mental makeup to endure such disenchantment for the better part of five hours. It should come as no surprise that also amounts to a who‚Äôs who of major championship stalwarts. On Saturday night, the first seven names on the leaderboard feature the last names Koepka (six under), Hovland (five under), Conners (five under), DeChambeau (three under), Rose (two under), Scheffler (two under) and McIlroy (one under).  ‚ÄúI think this tournament and especially in these conditions and on this golf course, the non-physical parts of the game I think are way more important this week than the physical parts of the game,‚Äù McIlroy said after it was over Saturday, his body language still recovering from the beating. ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôve done those well, and that‚Äôs the reason that I‚Äôm in a decent position.‚Äù  The eighth name of the leaderboard, however, is not a major championship regular ‚Äî nor a professional golf regular. He is PGA teaching professional Michael Block, who may be about the last person anyone expected to see six strokes off Koepka‚Äôs six-under lead come Sunday morning. Block was the cause of the eruption of noise on the 15th green behind McIlroy, his birdie on the hole igniting the upstate New York faithful.  What‚Äôs Block‚Äôs secret? Well, he may be the only PGA professional in the field silly enough to think he belongs there. And, as it turns out, he just might.  ‚ÄúNo. I mean, if anything, I love Rosey, but I can compete against these guys,‚Äù he said Saturday. ‚ÄúI can compete against them. I can hang. I can post a three or four under tomorrow, especially if I get the fairways rolling again.‚Äù  Block might not have a Tour pro‚Äôs driving distance or putting ability, but he has a major champion‚Äôs delusion. That, it turns out, was an absolutely essential piece of the puzzle in an inch of rain Saturday at Oak Hill, when no reasonable person would have believed earnestly that it was an enjoyable experience.  ‚ÄúI doubt if anybody on this entire property loves golf as much as I love golf. Period,‚Äù he said. ‚Äú[One day] I‚Äôll look back at this week and I‚Äôll say, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm glad you enjoyed it. I‚Äôm glad you enjoyed the moment.'‚Äù  Koepka, your 54-hole leader, certainly enjoyed the misery. A month after a decidedly uncharacteristic Sunday fade at the Masters, he stalked around Rochester like a hungry lion. On a day when only nine golfers shot rounds under par, Koepka shot 66, posting the round of the day by two strokes and placing himself a stroke clear of the field heading into Sunday.  ‚ÄúLearning what I learned at Augusta kind of helped today. To just never think the way I thought going into the final round. I won‚Äôt do it again the rest of my career,‚Äù Koepka said, although he chose not to elaborate on exactly what that thinking was. ‚ÄúThat doesn‚Äôt mean that you can‚Äôt go play bad ‚Äî you can play good, you‚Äôll play bad ‚Äî but I‚Äôll never have that mindset.‚Äù  Koepka entered Saturday with a sideshow within reason: his first major pairing with Bryson DeChambeau since the start of an acrimonious feud at this very tournament two years ago. But if there was a circus on Saturday, Koepka didn‚Äôt notice.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôll be honest with you, I don‚Äôt pay too much attention to who I‚Äôm playing with,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt talk a lot. I‚Äôm more focused on what I‚Äôve got to do. Especially today with the rain, trying to stay dry, there are other things to have to worry about.‚Äù  As we turn to Sunday, it‚Äôs unlikely the agony will stop. The weather will improve for the final round, but the challenge will not. Who knew the road to glory was paved with broken souls?  Evidently, McIlroy, who shared an all-too-familiar grimace when asked if he thought he could find a final-round 65.  ‚ÄúI hope so,‚Äù he said, pausing briefly. ‚ÄúI need to keep hope.‚Äù  On Sunday, the PGA Championship will crown a winner. But right now there are no winners.  Only survivors.

It‚Äôs hard to fathom the size of the universe. But two Stony Brook University professors are part of a project designed to do just that ‚Äî an effort scientists say is making advances.  Researchers in the NASA-backed project last week published an article in the journal Science detailing their work, which was done largely with the Hubble Space Telescope.  Simon Birrer, an assistant professor in Stony Brook‚Äôs Department of Physics and Astronomy, called the study ‚Äúa milestone‚Äù and cutting-edge in trying to determine the size of the universe.  The team consists of about 30 scientists from around the globe, with the majority in the United States. They include the lead author, Patrick Kelly from the University of Minnesota.  WHAT TO KNOW Two Stony Brook University professors are among the scientists participating in a NASA-backed project trying to determine the size of the universe.  are among the scientists participating in a NASA-backed project trying to determine the size of the universe. The researchers focused on a particular supernova ‚Äî or a star that suddenly dissolved through an explosion during which it increased its brightness tremendously.  on a particular supernova ‚Äî or a star that suddenly dissolved through an explosion during which it increased its brightness tremendously. By comparing where the supernova first appeared to where it appeared a year later, the scientists got an idea of how far away the supernova is ‚Äî and by extension how large the universe might be.  Their focus was on a supernova ‚Äî or a star that suddenly dissolved through a catastrophic explosion during which it increased its brightness tremendously. This one was, as Birrer put it in a bit of Star Wars lexicon, spotted in 2014 ‚Äúin a galaxy far, far away.‚Äù  Sign up for the Suffolk news this week newsletter The biggest news, politics and crime stories in Suffolk County, in your inbox every Friday at noon. By clicking Sign up, you agree to our privacy policy.  Researchers saw the supernova, called Refsdal, through NASA‚Äôs Hubble Space Telescope.  The scientists predicted where they would see yet another image of the very same light flare of the supernova exploding in 2015, which would give them an idea of how far away the supernova is ‚Äî and by extension how large the universe might be.  They were correct. The supernova Refsdal explosion was indeed visible again that year at the location they expected, Birrer said.  It wasn‚Äôt easy to find the supernovae, yet alone one that appears multiple times at different locations, due to a phenomenon called gravitational lensing, he said. Plus, supernova explosions are relatively rare ‚Äî perhaps one every 40 years in a galaxy.  ‚ÄúThe measurement of the expansion rate of the universe is a roller coaster,‚Äù Birrer said. But this project was an important advancement.  ‚ÄúThe prediction and subsequent observation of the fifth image of Supernova Refsdal was a great success,‚Äù said Anja von der Linden, an associate professor in Stony Brook‚Äôs Department of Physics and Astronomy who also took part in the study.  Von der Linden was part of the team that originally discovered Supernova Refsdal and prepared the follow-up Hubble observations.  Birrer was focused on the analysis of the measurement study, including the examination of the images of the supernova captured by the Hubble.  Soon, the researchers will be adding to their work a next-generation telescope in Chile, South America, called the Vera C. Rubin Observatory, which is especially geared to spot supernovas over a large area of the sky. Using it, they hope to locate about 50 supernovae a year.  Birrer said they got ‚Äúextremely lucky‚Äù in spotting supernova Refsdal with the Hubble telescope because it has a far smaller field of view and the timing had to be just right. The addition of the telescope in Chile should allow scientists to find supernovas at a rate 100 times faster, he said.  Sherry Suyu, an associate professor at the Technical Institute in Munich, Germany, who was not involved in the study, said spotting supernovas the way the researchers did has ‚Äúbeen very rare until now,‚Äù but with the addition of the telescope in Chile they ‚Äúare expected to have hundreds of such events. We are entering an exciting era with lensed supernovae!‚Äù  Wendy Freedman, a professor in the University of Chicago‚Äôs Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, who also was not involved in the study called its findings ‚Äúan interesting and important contribution to‚Äù figuring out the size and history of the universe, though some issues remain to be resolved before scientists can get a final, more accurate figure.  Grasping the size of the universe is a somewhat mind-boggling exercise. The solar system with the eight planets including Earth that are revolving around the Sun is part of one galaxy ‚Äî the Milky Way. And the Milky Way Galaxy has some 100 billion stars ‚Äî the Sun is just one of them, Birrer said.  In the universe, there are tens of billions of galaxies, all with about as many stars as the Milky Way Galaxy, he said.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to grasp the dimension, even after studying the universe for more than a decade myself,‚Äù Birrer said, adding, ‚ÄúI guess we have to accept that we are just little fish in a big ocean.‚Äù  He added that it has been hard for humans to learn much about the universe, because it is so massive and inaccessible to travel to.  What scientists have learned mostly ‚Äúcomes from just staring at it and see what the universe reveals to us,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúOur detective work is probably very similar to that of archaeologists. Astrophysicists are able to collect tiny fragments of the past and have to reconstruct a rich and dynamic history of the universe that still holds back many mysteries."  As recently as 500 years ago, scientists and everyone else still believed the Earth was the center of the universe and our solar system, with the other planets and Sun revolving around it. It wasn‚Äôt until Nicolaus Copernicus‚Äôs studies in the 1500s that we understood the Earth and other planets revolve around the Sun.  Scientists estimate the age of the universe at between 12.6 billion and 13.6 billion years. The new research project should also help calculate the number more precisely, Birrer said.

ST. LOUIS ‚Äì It‚Äôs graduation weekend for thousands of students in the St. Louis area. St. Louis University alumni John O‚ÄôLeary didn‚Äôt graduate at the top of his class back in 1999, but he does have a harrowing and inspiring story he shared with new SLU graduates.  Back in 1987, O‚ÄôLeary watched a group of older children in his neighborhood playing with fire and gasoline. He was in a horrific accident and given a 1% chance of survival.  ‚ÄúI assumed, if they can do it, so can I,‚Äù said O‚ÄôLeary. ‚ÄúWith my parents gone, I walked into the garage, bent over a can of gasoline, and poured a little bit of fluid on top. [A] huge explosion, [I] find myself engulfed. [I] spent five and a half months in burn center, burned 100 percent of my body, lost my fingers.‚Äù  O‚ÄôLeary attributes his professional success to his time at SLU, and he left the Class of 2023 feeling moved and empowered.  ‚ÄúWhat a phenomenal commencement address,‚Äù Rodney Mosquito said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an honor to be in the presence of someone who has overcome so many challenges. It just reminds me that I can do anything if I put my mind to it.‚Äù  SLU graduate Chloe Kepros added, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs awesome to hear from someone who‚Äôs also a fellow SLU student and who has been through things and come out the other side and is able to show, you know, where their life is now.‚Äù  But O‚ÄôLeary stays humble.  ‚ÄúI was not an elite student and would not have been voted most likely to succeed,‚Äù he said.  Close Thanks for signing up! Watch for us in your inbox.  And he didn‚Äôt always feel comfortable sharing what happened to him.  ‚ÄúI was invited by a Girl Scout to speak at her school,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd I made the mistake of saying yes. So that first event led to another, and another, and another.‚Äù  Now he‚Äôs spoken 2,600 times in front of millions of people.  ‚ÄúNot out of arrogance or ego, but to serve the one in front of us,‚Äù he explained.  He is grateful for his parents‚Äô unconditional love. In 2004, they wrote a book called ‚ÄúOverwhelming Odds.‚Äù Now, O‚ÄôLeary has written two books himself.  ‚ÄúI have a book called ‚ÄòOn Fire,‚Äô [and] another book is called ‚ÄòIn Awe,‚Äô‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre both bestsellers. Just recently there are individuals in Hollywood who realized, man, we want this story to go far beyond St. Louis and far beyond books or speaking.‚Äù  As the Class of 2023 navigates the ups and downs of their own life stories, O‚ÄôLeary wants them to remember this: ‚ÄúWhether they‚Äôre in the front row or the last row, their life matters.‚Äù  St. Louis University also recognized O‚ÄôLeary as an honorary degree recipient on Saturday. Around 3,000 students are graduating from SLU this month.

Listen to this story:  Have you ever wondered how the Christogram IHS typically seen on liturgical items originated from? Or who was the first beatified millennial?  In our free ebook, we highlight the lives of five holy men and women, and how their example of courage, faith, and innovation in their time can inspire parish leaders in their daily work today. We walk you through the lives of:  Paul, the Apostle  Isidore of Seville  Bernardine of Siena  Blessed Carlo Acutis  Frances Cabrini  We also share the wisdom of St. John Paul II, prayers for parish leaders, and the four most important characteristics that every parish leader needs in order to serve well in today‚Äôs Church.  For a long time, parishes relied on word of mouth to attract new people to join them in celebrating the Mass and the sacraments, either through a personal invitation from a parishioner or the pastor himself. Bulletins, pulpit announcements, and emails were the go-to communication tools for leaders to keep parishioners informed. But with a shrinking population of Christians every year, these methods of growing the Church aren‚Äôt enough.  Seeing the cultural and religious shifts happening around him and the explosion of new forms of technology, St. John Paul II met with the Pontifical Council for Social Communications in 2002. Before imparting his Apostolic Blessing on the people and work of the council, he shared his concerns and challenged his brother bishops and sisters in Christ to take advantage of new opportunities:  ‚ÄúThe Gospel lives always in conversation with culture, for the Eternal Word never ceases to be present to the Church and to humanity. If the Church holds back from culture, the Gospel itself falls silent. Therefore, we must be fearless in crossing the cultural threshold of the communications and information revolution now taking place‚Ä¶  ‚ÄúTherefore, dear Brothers and Sisters, I urge you, in all your planning, to make room for Christ. In the print media, in radio and television, in the world of cinema and the Internet, seek to open doors to him who so mercifully is the door of salvation for us. Then the mass media will be a world of genuine communication, a world not of illusion but of truth and joy. I pray fervently that this will be so, and I entrust your work to Mary, Mother of the Word made flesh. I gladly impart my Apostolic Blessing to all involved in the work of the Pontifical Council, as a pledge of Christ‚Äôs presence among you and his power upon all that you do in his name.‚Äù=  Decades later, the words of St. John Paul II are bearing fruit in the Church.  74 percent of parishes who participated in our Catholic edition of the 2023 State of Church Tech report indicated that they offered worship services both in-person and online. The Church is sharing, experimenting, and extending its ministries‚Äîand in response, people are exploring their Catholic Faith in digital spaces like never before.  But for some parishes, making meaningful improvements to parish life is difficult. It can feel impossible to get everyone on board.  This free ebook will help leaders discover how the faith, courage, and innovation of saints from centuries ago can impact their leadership today. Download your free ebook today.

‚ÄúFast X‚Äù is now out in cinemas everywhere and with it has come plenty of chatter regarding the film‚Äôs numerous cameos, the cliffhanger ending previously teased by its stars, and the various turns the story takes.  MAJOR SPOILERS AHEAD FOR ‚ÄúFAST X‚Äù  The film‚Äôs director Louis Leterrier has spoken with several outlets about some of the creative choices made in regard to the film. First up, he chatted with EW about John Cena‚Äôs character Jakob and his death.  In the film‚Äôs final action set piece, Jakob is transporting Dom‚Äôs son Brian (Leo Abelo Perry) to safety when Dante (Jason Momoa) kidnaps him. Dom pursues him, but Jakob realizes he must protect Dom and the kid ‚Äì sacrificing himself to kill Dante‚Äôs men in a massive explosion.  The move marks the end of Cena‚Äôs involvement in the franchise following his introduction as the villain in ‚ÄúF9‚Äù. Letterier says the death was an idea he came up with early on after meeting Cena ‚Äì and the news upset the actor a bit:  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm like, ‚ÄòThat man can be a badass but cannot be a bad guy. There‚Äôs no mean bone in his body. I said to John, ‚ÄòYou will have to sacrifice yourself, to give the ultimate gift to your brother to save his son,‚Äô and it upset him. I pitched him between two takes as I‚Äôm over there resetting the camera. I pitched him this thing and then he loved it. And that literally changed his performance because he understood where he was going. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going to give so much love so then the sacrifice really hurts.‚Äô And it really does hurt.‚Äù  Of course, does anyone really die in this franchise? The series is famous for resurrecting multiple seemingly dead characters, and does so again here with at least one of the cameos being Gal Gadot returnning as Gisele ‚Äì last seen fallout out a plane in ‚ÄúFast 6‚Äù. The reveal has raised the obvious question as to whether Han (Sung Kang) knew Gisele was alive the whole time.  Gadot confirmed her return a few hours ago on Instagram, posting photos and saying: ‚ÄúMissed my Fast family! I‚Äôm overwhelmed with excitement. To my fans, your continuous love and support fuels this journey. Here‚Äôs to honoring the legacy, the fans and the Fast Family that we‚Äôve built together!‚Äù  Meanwhile, the film ends on a cliffhanger with a plane explosion seemingly taking out at least four regulars (albeit behind a hill) whilst Dante prepares to blow a dam that could seemingly kill Dom and his son.  ‚ÄúFast X Part 2,‚Äù whether it be the second half of this story of the middle part of a trilogy, is slated to debut in 2025.

DAYTON ‚Äî A robbery suspect led officers and deputies from multiple jurisdictions on a high-speed pursuit Sunday overnight.  >> TRENDING: 1 hospitalized after home explosion in Shelby County  Middletown Police first initiated a chase on a robbery suspect who stole a white Mercedes-Benz SUV and fled from officers, dispatchers for Montgomery County Regional and the Dayton post of Ohio State Highway Patrol confirmed. However, the exact location and time the pursuit began remained undisclosed.  During the chase, the Dayton post of Ohio State Highway Patrol were called upon to assist as the suspect continued to flee on a highway‚Äîinside the state troopers‚Äô jurisdiction.  Middletown Police then ended their chase once the suspect fled the city‚Äôs borders, at which time officers requested aid from neighboring law enforcement agencies.  Dayton Police began their pursuit of the runaway suspect at U.S. Route 35 near Edwin C. Moses Boulevard at 1:19 a.m., about 25 miles away, Montgomery County dispatchers said.  The suspect was heading eastbound, reaching top speeds of approximately 100 mph.  Officers and deputies were unable to reach the vehicle or capture the suspect at the time of reporting.  Dayton Police led the investigation into the high-speed chase, according to dispatchers for the Ohio State Highway Patrol.      ¬© 2023 Cox Media Group

Former KGB and security boss Nikolai Patrushev told of a 'radioactive cloud' drifting across Europe after Russian strikes hit a uranium supply - the claim has since been debunked as propaganda  Apocalyptic claims from one of Putin's closest henchmen of a radioactive cloud heading across Europe have been ridiculed by experts.  The doomsday prediction was made by Nikolai Patrushev, who has alleged the deadly cloud was wafting west from Ukraine after Russian troops hit an arms depot containing depleted uranium ammunition supplied by the UK government.  Ex-KGB Patrushev is secretary of Russia's security council and reportedly one of warlord Putin's closest security aides and maintained flames erupted high into the sky in a fiery mushroom cloud after the hit.  But after declaring Poland had already seen soaring levels of radiation following the strike, Patrushev was quickly shut down by experts who described the claims as propaganda.  ‚ÄúTheir destruction caused a radioactive cloud now moving towards Western Europe,‚Äù Patrushev's statement said.  ‚ÄúAnd Poland has already recorded an increase in radiation.‚Äù  Image: Channel1/e2w) Channel1/e2w)  The former FSB chief and war hawk also claimed at a meeting in Syktyvkar: ‚ÄúFurthermore, the US is developing and already using chemical and biological weapons, including in Ukraine.  ‚ÄúSo that‚Äôs what American aid and democracy is all about.‚Äù  Russian state TV which prominently broadcast Patrushev‚Äôs claim said he was referring to a strike on a facility in Khmelnytskyi.  ‚ÄúA column of smoke from the explosion rose several hundred metres and a prolonged detonation followed,‚Äù stated Channel One.  ‚ÄúThen there was a rise in radioactivity in the area.‚Äù  Image: Channel1/e2w) Channel1/e2w)  But experts from Khmelnytskyi National University had ‚Äúdebunked Russian fakes about an increase in radiation levels in the city following the attack by Russian forces on the night of 13 May,‚Äù reported Ukrinform.  ‚ÄúPreviously, Russian propaganda began spreading information on social media and news channels about an increased radiation background in Khmelnytskyi, allegedly caused by an explosion damaging either low-enriched uranium shells or components of a bomb sent to Ukraine.‚Äù  A statement from the university said: ‚ÄúThere is no reason to be concerned.‚Äù  In Lublin, Poland the Maria Curie-Sk≈Çodowska University said a supposed rise in radioactivity in the country - as highlighted by Patrushev - was a natural phenomenon linked to rainfall.  A spike in bismuth was caused by precipitation.  Image: Channel1/e2w) Channel1/e2w)  Independent Russian journalist Ilya Shepelin said: ‚ÄúAt its peak, on Monday, it was‚Ä¶.five million times lower than a life-threatening dose.‚Äù  Patrushev‚Äôs radioactive cloud threat late on Friday was mocked by the Procurator Telegram channel which ridiculed the septuagenarian as a candidate for ‚Äúa medal in the field of nuclear physics‚Äù.  ‚ÄúPerhaps Patrushev forgot to put his glasses on, and did not see that the uranium was depleted, and therefore there was no way a radioactive cloud could come out of it,‚Äù it stated.  ‚ÄúIn a word, the Europeans will not even notice this nightmarish threat, just like the infamous freezing [from halted gas supplies] in winter.‚Äù  Similarly, Patrushev provided no evidence for the constantly repeated Russian claim that the US is developing and deploying chemical and biological weapons in Ukraine.  Image: Getty Images) Getty Images)  In March, Russia accused Britain of triggering ‚Äúgenocide‚Äù by supplying Ukraine with depleted uranium tank shells.  Putin said he ‚Äúwill have to respond properly since the collective West will be using weapons with a nuclear component‚Äù.  Britain accused the Russians of ‚Äúdeliberately trying to disinform‚Äù over a ‚Äústandard component and has nothing to do with nuclear weapons or capabilities‚Äù.  But Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova hit back declaring: ‚ÄúThe use of ammunition with depleted uranium is a manifestation of genocide of the population against which it is used and the people who use them.‚Äù  They would cause radioactive damage to ‚Äúeveryone‚Äù living in the place where the depleted uranium tank shells are released.  ‚ÄúThey receive it, and it‚Äôs not a one-time problem‚Ä¶they will live with this forever.‚Äù  This was a ‚Äúscientifically proven fact‚Äù based on their use in former Yugoslavia, she alleged.

If you were to make a wild stab at which books were the most popular, what would you choose? Your personal favourites ‚Äî say, mysteries, or big sagas, blockbuster reads from writers such as John Irving or Stephen King?  The book industry is having a fine romance: with books about love.  Romance for a new generation  One of the authors who has helped cement the place of romance in the popular imagination ‚Äî or at least on the bestsellers lists ‚Äî is Colleen Hoover. Her ‚ÄúIt Ends With Us‚Äù was the No. 1 bestselling book in Canada in 2022. According to BookNet Canada, Hoover‚Äôs books alone drove a 55-per-cent increase in the romance category when compared with 2021, with five of her titles topping the list.  The same trend was seen in the United States. Publishers Weekly reported that ‚Äúunit sales of fiction titles rose 8.5 per cent over 2021, led by a 52.4-per-cent increase in sales of romance books.‚Äù And those sales were driven in large part by, you guessed it, Colleen Hoover.  ‚ÄúThe list of bestselling romance titles in 2022 is ‚Ä¶ led by Colleen Hoover, whose ‚ÄòIt Starts With Us‚Äô and ‚ÄòIt Ends With Us‚Äô topped the romance charts. Those two books, along with a handful of other Hoover titles, resulted in a banner year for Simon & Schuster ‚Ä¶‚Äù  Hoover is published in Canada by Simon & Schuster, which noted in an email to the Star that the author has sold more than 24 million copies of her English-language books ‚Äúin all formats‚Äù across the world. It has seen its sales of romance books ‚Äúskyrocket‚Äù as a result.  Much of this traffic is driven by younger readers. According to BookNet Canada, the hashtag #RomanceRecs has more than 390 million views on TikTok, ‚Äúan undeniable source of influence on book-reading behaviour.‚Äù It‚Äôs an observation that Simon & Schuster echoes.  ‚ÄúAn increasing number of younger, and often more diverse readers have discovered and embraced this genre, much of it fuelled by BookTok,‚Äù the publisher said in a statement. ‚ÄúWhere sales have traditionally been driven by retailer merchandising and press coverage, a lot of the original buzz for these books was driven by enthusiastic BookTok readers.‚Äù  The Harlequin effect  There used to be a saying: that 4.1 Harlequin romances sold around the world every second. That particular publisher was, at one time, the first name that sprang to mind when the words ‚Äúbooks‚Äù and ‚Äúromance‚Äù were mentioned.  And it‚Äôs still going strong. Dianne Moggy, vice-president of editorial for the Harlequin Brand Group, which includes 11 category lines, noted that they publish more than 800 romance titles a year. And they‚Äôre not all those paperbacks we remember from our parents‚Äô bookcases or grocery store shelves: roughly 40 per cent of their books sell digitally.  The genre‚Äôs popularity has driven a deep change in the content of books and an increased focus on giving readers what they want.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve really been trying to increase the representation across every series we publish,‚Äù Moggy said. ‚ÄúSo we‚Äôre trying to ensure that our readers are actually seeing themselves reflected in the books ‚Ä¶ whether it‚Äôs race and ethnicity or body image or neurodiversity.‚Äù  Those concerns have translated into sales in the Canadian market. BookNet Canada recorded that sales in romance featuring LGBTQ characters increased by 10,406 per cent between 2017 and 2022, with sales from 2020 to ‚Äô21 increasing 301 per cent, and from ‚Äô21 to ‚Äô22 by 136 per cent. Fiction romance in the workplace rose by 1,793 per cent during that five-year period, and for African American and Black categories by 1,733 per cent.  The desire for more representative romance is an aspect of the genre that attracts Muslim writer Uzma Jalaluddin, whose latest, ‚ÄúMuch Ado About Nada,‚Äù comes out in June.  ‚ÄúI‚Äôm attracted to the subversive aspects of romance, the ways that romance writers (like myself) use the tropes and expectations of this genre to explore other issues, such as identity, immigration or prejudice,‚Äù she said. And so she writes love stories set in immigrant neighbourhoods with South Asian, Muslim characters.  ‚ÄúWhen I wrote ‚ÄòMuch Ado About Nada‚Äô I set it in a massive Muslim conference in Toronto,‚Äù said Jalaluddin. ‚ÄúAs much as my book is a swoony second-chance romance, it‚Äôs also about Muslims having fun and inviting the reader into their space.  ‚ÄúAfter all, love is love no matter who you are, how you dress or what you believe. Also, no one else was writing them. (I‚Äôm glad that‚Äôs changing now.)‚Äù  Stomping on the tropes and using them in new ways  HarperCollins, whose parent company News Corp. bought Harlequin from the Toronto Star‚Äôs parent company, Torstar Corp., for $455 million in 2014, is like many publishers, increasing the number of trade paperback or hardcover romances it offers.  ‚ÄúI think the definition of romance has spilled into a number of different areas,‚Äù said Margaret O‚ÄôNeill Marbury, a VP at HarperCollins, responsible for trade titles at the company that owns Harlequin.  Popular American writer Curtis Sittenfeld, who publishes with Random House, has recently waded into the genre with her latest novel, ‚ÄúRomantic Comedy.‚Äù  It sets up an interesting dynamic, showing at first the typical dorky, not-so-good-looking guy with the gorgeous model. Then she flips that trope on its head by having the dorky, not-so-gorgeous writer develop a crush on a famous pop star who used to date models.  The book becomes an examination of gender relations and the rituals of romance, yes, but it also does something traditional romances do: has an emotional arc, strong characters you can relate to, some drama that keeps them apart and, well, a happy ending.  ‚ÄúI thought that it would be fun. That was my main motivation. I started it in the summer of 2021,‚Äù said Sittenfeld in an interview. ‚ÄúSo it was the pandemic, I guess it was about 15 months or 16 months in, and it felt like a pretty dark time, I think, globally and personally. I definitely wrote ‚ÄòRomantic Comedy‚Äô for escapist pleasure for myself. And then I hoped, eventually, for readers.‚Äù  ‚ÄúSome people will say that romance is just ChickLit reinvented,‚Äù said Canadian author Chantel Guertin, whose latest book is ‚ÄúTwo for the Road.‚Äù  She argued that romance now is not ‚Äúa 20-something girl who‚Äôs bumbling through life trying to find a guy. Now the heroines are so strong and they are self-assured, and very successful and have great careers. That romance element is part of it, but as a person they have got it figured out.‚Äù  And, while in the more traditional romance, the happy ending is a must, commercial or trade fiction stories don‚Äôt always have to have one, Marbury said, ‚Äúbut they do have to be hopeful,‚Äù and there still has to be a strong relationship or pull between the characters. Think of writers such as Nicholas Sparks, Emily Giffin and Jojo Moyes.  The ‚Äúhappily ever after‚Äù is the point  But the happy ending has a big role to play, and a lot of readers and writers like it that way.  Romance book sales grew throughout the pandemic, a time of uncertainty, as Guertin pointed out. ‚ÄúWe often felt as if we had no control of our situations and we certainly didn‚Äôt know what things were going to look like in the next few months.  ‚ÄúOnce you know the book is going to end happily, you remove that layer of unsettling and uncertainty, and then you actually enjoy the ride of the journey of the story, which actually is often very complex,‚Äù Guertin said. ‚ÄúAnd you can really delve into the characters and their stories because you‚Äôre not concerned about how it‚Äôs going to end.‚Äù  And you can escape from the reality of the everyday.  Jalaluddin, too, is a believer in the happily-ever-after ending. ‚ÄúPartly this is because I‚Äôm a hopeless romantic, wrapped in the outer trappings of a cynic,‚Äù she said.  ‚ÄúBut mostly it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm attracted to optimistic stories that demonstrate the good in humanity; and romance novels, with their focus on love, relationships, problem-solving, a dash of adventure or intrigue, are at their heart heaped with optimism. It is baked into the very DNA of the genre, because no matter what else happens there will be a happy ending for all. Who can resist that?‚Äù  Certainly not the readers buying those millions of romance books being sold every year and those who, during the pandemic, turned to the genre for an emotional and psychological lift.  Can artificial intelligence write us a love story?  As romance continues to modernize its approach, it seems as if it might be particularly vulnerable to being written, perhaps unknowingly to readers, by artificial intelligence, including ChatGPT and others. With its fairly predictable structure, it would seem a particularly promising genre for AI to target.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not looking to AI to generate content at all,‚Äù said Moggy. ‚ÄúBut it‚Äôs a big concern in terms of the number of submissions we get and how do we police that?‚Äù  She noted that they received a submission earlier in the week we spoke and weren‚Äôt sure whether it was AI-generated or not. ‚ÄúBut it certainly is very similar to another book we have published.‚Äù  While AI might be helpful in terms of writing marketing copy based on metadata, for example, when it comes to the creative process and content, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs where I get very nervous about things,‚Äù said Marbury.  It‚Äôs romance, after all. And doesn‚Äôt it all come down to love? Can an algorithm capture emotion? It‚Äôs a question we‚Äôve been asking since Hal in ‚Äú2001: A Space Odyssey.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI think you‚Äôve hit the real point here,‚Äù said Moggy. ‚ÄúCan it bring the emotion, which is what the reader connects to ‚Ä¶ if that emotion is missed, then I think you‚Äôd miss what the romance reader is looking for.‚Äù  Hopefully, for the industry ‚Äî and writers and readers ‚Äî this will result in a happy ending.
